text: What does it mean to collaborate?
That’s easy.
We share something together.
Could be a piece of information.
Something that makes us all better.
Something that makes us all grow.
We’re doing it right now, actually.
But what if what we’re sharing is confidential?
What if sharing opens us up to vulnerabilities?
How do we collaborate with less risk?
When companies need to match their collective data
to better predict financial risk,
gain consumer insights,
and make advertising more relevant,
things get a bit tricky.
Why?
Because it’s hard to build secure environments
that allow these companies to keep data private,
isolated and protected at all times.
This is why we created AWS Clean Rooms.
To help companies and their partners
easily and securely analyze and collaborate on their combined datasets
—without sharing or revealing underlying data.
It’s collaboration without revealing information that is best kept private.
This is Jared, who works at 605,
an independent TV measurement firm.
He spends his free time designing and modeling 3D printed projects.
It’s my job to make sure that all of the engineers and analysts
are able to use our services without issue.
AWS Clean Rooms helps Jared and his customers
analyze data and gain insights about media viewership
that they couldn’t learn without collaboration.
And this is Kemal,
a die-hard sports fan,
who loves his family and his dog…
Gizmo
Kemal works at Dish Media
When it comes to information,
my job to ensure everyone plays by the rules.
With AWS Clean Rooms
Kemal and Dish can use privacy-enhancing tools
that help keep data safe during collaborations.
Companies like 605 and Dish Media
can create their own clean rooms in a few minutes
and securely analyze data with other companies using flexible,
easy-to-configure queries to gain insights that fit their specific needs.
All wins,
No losses.
Welcome to the evolution of collaboration.
